text: one of the surprising things to me when
I started learning about clinical
genetics was that almost all genetics is
risk genetics you know I had the idea
that if you had a mutation it was going
to cause a disease and there was nothing
you could do about it and so I think I
share that perception with a lot of the
the public that it's very deterministic
and it turns out that it is not even in
those cases where you've got a very
dominant mutation that's running through
a family it can afflict people at
different points in their life at
different ages and two different severa
tease so every gene is really a risk
gene and we're always talking about risk
and that was a big surprise to me now I
think what's happening with with is that
there's a huge over expectation of what
genomics can tell us about our health
and that's gradually going to be
corrected over time in society partly
because of education and research and
partly because people will go ahead and
get their genomic information and as
I've heard from a lot of them they'll
say what what is this all you know is
this what is this all I've got but
they'll also have to understand a little
bit more about statistics we talked
about that ahead of time and and they're
going to have to understand that Wow a
40-percent increased risk that sounds
pretty scary but if you're increase in
risk goes from one percent to less than
two percent that really doesn't mean
very much and that's where we are with a
lot of these things that are available
today your risk of heart disease goes
from one point two percent to
one-point-six percent and that's a
significant percentage but it's really
still a very small risk
